dt: {bc}a liking formed by caprice rather than reason {bc}{sx|inclination||}

dt.t: She took a {wi}fancy{/wi} to the young man.

dt: {bc}an image or representation of something formed in the mind
{bc}imagination especially of a capricious or delusive sort

dt.t: His plans to build a new stadium are the product of pure {wi}fancy{/wi}.

dt: {bc}the power of conception and representation used in artistic expression (as by a poet)
{bc}devotees of some particular art, practice, or amusement
{bc}the object of interest of such a fancy

et: Middle English {it}fantasie, fantsy, fansey{/it} "the imagination as a faculty, mental image produced by this faculty, deluded notion, figment of the imagination, preference directed by caprice rather than reason, liking" {ma}{mat|fantasy:1|}{/ma}

The disyllabic form, a rare variant of {it}fantasie{/it} {et_link|fantasy:1|fantasy:1} in Middle English, became more common and began to separate in sense from {it}fantasie/fantasy{/it} in early Modern English.
shortdef: a liking formed by caprice rather than reason : inclination

dt.t: He's all right, I suppose, but I can't say that I {wi}fancy{/wi} him.
Just {wi}fancy{/wi} my surprise when I heard that he was getting married.
she {it}fancied{/it} she had met him before

pt: {sc}think{/sc} {sc}conceive{/sc} {sc}imagine{/sc} {sc}fancy{/sc} {sc}realize{/sc} {sc}envisage{/sc} {sc}envision{/sc} mean to form an idea of. {sc}think{/sc} implies the entrance of an idea into one's mind with or without deliberate consideration or reflection.

pt.t: I just {it}thought{/it} of a good joke

pt: {sc}conceive{/sc} suggests the forming and bringing forth and usually developing of an idea, plan, or design.
{sc}fancy{/sc} suggests an imagining often unrestrained by reality but spurred by desires.
{sc}realize{/sc} stresses a grasping of the significance of what is conceived or imagined.

pt.t: {it}realized{/it} the enormity of the task ahead

pt: {sc}envisage{/sc} and {sc}envision{/sc} imply a conceiving or imagining that is especially clear or detailed.

et: Middle English {it}fantasien, fantesien, fancyen{/it} "to plan, devise, create, form (an idea), imagine (something false), desire," in part derivative of {it}fantasie, fantsy, fansey {/it} {et_link|fancy:2|fancy:2}, in part borrowed from Middle French {it}fantasier{/it} "to imagine, invent," verbal derivative of {it}fantasie{/it} {et_link|fantasy:1|fantasy:1}
shortdef: to have a fancy for : like
to form a conception of : imagine
to believe mistakenly or without evidence
